item.title: US, EU and free speech
item.description: AT PRESENT, there is a pot-calling-the-kettle-black approach being taken by the European Union and the United States regarding the imposition of sanctions upon individuals deemed hostile to free speech. On December 23, the US state department announced that it would bar five European citizens accused of spearheading efforts to pressure US tech giants to censor......

item.title: The world after 2025
item.description: AS THE world approaches 2026, uncertainty has become a defining feature of global affairs. Unlike previous eras, today’s unpredictability stems not only from cyclical economic swings or traditional political rivalries but from a combination of technological disruption, shifting geopolitical alliances and unexpected crises that redefine the global landscape. These......

item.title: Indigenous lore as climate ally
item.description: MODERN way of life has become so deeply ingrained that shifting towards simpler, more rational consumption habits is increasingly challenging. We are conditioned to prioritise cheap, disposable goods over durable alternatives, even when doing so produces more waste. This pattern reflects a psychological bias favouring immediate gratification over long-term......

item.title: Crisis of house rental
item.description: FOR centuries, Old Town, the old quarters of Bangladesh’s capital, has stood as a testament to resilience, craftsmanship and collective life. Its narrow lanes, dense neighbourhoods and ageing houses have sheltered generations of families who built the city’s commercial networks and cultural traditions. Yet beneath this architectural charm, a quieter and deeper crisis is......

item.title: Govt must hold criminals behind madrassahs to justice
item.description: AN EXPLOSION at the Ummul Qura International Madrassah at Hasnabad of Dakshin Keraniganj in Dhaka at about 10:30am on December 26 left the walls of two rooms of the building damaged and four people, including a woman and two children, wounded. The police, who raided the place, seized crude bombs, materials used to make bombs and inflammable liquids......

item.title: Fuel prices should reflect global trends, not profits
item.description: FUEL prices that continue to remain high in Bangladesh despite a sustained fall on the world market is alarming. At a time when international petroleum markets ease, consumers at home continue to shoulder inflated fuel costs as the state-owned Bangladesh Petroleum Corporation retains elevated prices. Official data show that the corporation recorded a net profit of Tk......
